article.title: Donn
article.paragraph: Other usesAccording toIrish mythology,Donn, orthe Dark One, is the Lord of the Dead and father ofDiarmuid Ua Duibhne, whom he gave toAengusAengus gto be nurtured. Donn is regarded as the father of theIrish peopleIrish race; a position similar to that ofDis Paterand theGauls, as noted byJulius Caesar.

Originally, Donn was the chief of the Sons of Mil, a mythological race who invadedIreland, ousting theTuatha D Danann. Donn slightedriu, one of theeponymousgoddesses of Ireland, and he was drowned off the south-west coast of the island. A place near this spot, on a small rocky island named 'Tech nDuinn' ('the House of Donn'), became Donn's dwelling place as god of the dead. This house was the assembly place for the dead before they began the journey to theOtherworld. He is similar in some regards to theHindudeityYama.

Knockfierna,County Limerickwas Donn Frinne's residence. Cnoc Frinne (meaning 'Hill of Truth') takes its name from Donn, who is said to forewarn the local people of bad weather by gathering up rain clouds around him on the hill.
Donn is also associated withDoonbeg, County Clare, specifically the sand dunes located near the modern-day golf course.In modernIrish languageIrish, the word for the colourbrownis "donn".
